Unlike the painter or the musician, the writer is exposed to
innumerable, outlying, inappropriate, irrelevant
solicitations. Why not write the history of your parish?
or the life of some Roman Emperor? Or

compliment your patron? Why not take part in the 
            govt
            government
           of your
country? And advise the soul of its dangers? Why not
become pamphleter, historian, moralist? – There is the
press, ready to accept anything. And as the public becomes
more learned, as glass is filled into windows & pillows
be replace logs, the public adds its invitation to the
writer – It is an inquisitve, active minded
public, & it soon duplicates the writer takes hold of
Anon, & makes him into the familiar voice,
with which talks an easy subject: only a few
keep to the old art way: & still persist in
giving to words a certain making words into works of art,
the author
Anon died round about 1477. It was the printed
book with the author's name attached that killed him.
After that the audience was separate from the singer.

audience sang, the voice that filled the pause,

chorus

It is in the Elizabethan great house that
the influences that told upon the writer, who has
just emerged from medieval anonymity
are to be found. Since no The artist, the
writer who makes words exactly fit his emotions,

there was much to stimulate it. There were the crimsons &
the greens & the blues of the clothing: the ear was
also highly [in the aloud?] pricked. Books were read aloud.
Each word was given the sharpness & substance of the
speaking voice And then music – the lords &
ladies sang his words; added to their sharpness &
substance, lilt, rhythm, melody. And he was
and his material, his store of words, were fluid,

was an open question. The arts then were

Here & there
Here & there, in one of their
great houses,
at Gorhambury old Lady Bacon sat at her table writing
dispatches, involved, circuitous, forma dispatches to her son.
the phrasing is as intricate & formal as a state title
She She drops into Latin & French. She advises,
admonishes, preaches; it is a letter written from the
pulpit. Yet the violent, & [private?], & resonant
The The sound of the bible is in her ears. She only
If she condescends to ment mention strawberries, it is with a
scowl & a scold. They are full of a the [illeg.] of their,
the danger of the time, written not from a mother to a son,
but from a counsellor to a confederate. If she
condescends to mention strawberry it is with a
[sharpness?] & angularity & warning.
And the name of god is always on her lips:
"God
keep us in the faith & send us health & a care to
to please God above all....
The violent, suspicious, intemperate, crossgrained old
woman, always suspicious, always in dread, always
in fear that her letters be read by some fox, some
pryer or [prober?]; preaches, admonishes, exhorts.
The Bible is the loa model. The bible, which was the
"best seller". And the prose of the bible, cannot
lend itself to the secular lives. The prose of the bible

intimate prose style. Writing is still a
formal expressive art. Prose is not accommodated does not adhere to
the simple, the easy, the natural. It is a
garment only to be put on when the mind is
in a exact & dignified.

The Elizabethans are violent & infatuated
long winded & intolerably contorted as people
because they took the bible for their model
private letters. They are never simple, easy, genial natural.
They are never subtle. They are unshaded. Vi Carnation &

prose as stiff as their clothes. Inevitably we

when their farthingales & ruffs; we build up
